trans-unit.source: Correlate events over time with Storm and HBase on HDInsight
trans-unit.target: Correlate events over time with Storm and HBase on HDInsight

trans-unit.source: Learn how to correlate events that arrive at different times by using Storm and HBase on HDInsight.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to correlate events that arrive at different times by using Storm and HBase on HDInsight.

trans-unit.source: Correlate events over time with Storm and HBase on HDInsight
trans-unit.target: Correlate events over time with Storm and HBase on HDInsight

trans-unit.source: By using a persistent data store with Apache Storm, you can correlate data entries that arrive at different times.
trans-unit.target: By using a persistent data store with Apache Storm, you can correlate data entries that arrive at different times.

trans-unit.source: For example, linking login and logout events for a user session to calculate how long the session lasted.
trans-unit.target: For example, linking login and logout events for a user session to calculate how long the session lasted.

trans-unit.source: In this document, you will learn how to create a basic C# Storm topology that tracks login and logout events for user sessions, and calculates the duration of the session.
trans-unit.target: In this document, you will learn how to create a basic C# Storm topology that tracks login and logout events for user sessions, and calculates the duration of the session.

trans-unit.source: The topology uses HBase as a persistent data store.
trans-unit.target: The topology uses HBase as a persistent data store.

trans-unit.source: HBase also allows you to perform batch queries on the historical data to produce additional insights, such as how many user sessions were started or ended during a specific time period.
trans-unit.target: HBase also allows you to perform batch queries on the historical data to produce additional insights, such as how many user sessions were started or ended during a specific time period.

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: HDInsight tools for Visual Studio: See <link><linkText>Get started using the HDInsight tools for Visual Studio</linkText><title></title></link> for installation information.
trans-unit.target: HDInsight tools for Visual Studio: See <link><linkText>Get started using the HDInsight tools for Visual Studio</linkText><title></title></link> for installation information.

trans-unit.source: Apache Storm on HDInsight cluster
trans-unit.target: Apache Storm on HDInsight cluster

trans-unit.source: Apache HBase on HDInsight cluster
trans-unit.target: Apache HBase on HDInsight cluster

trans-unit.source: Architecture
trans-unit.target: Architecture

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Diagram of the data flow through the topology</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Diagram of the data flow through the topology</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Correlating events requires a common identifier for the event source.
trans-unit.target: Correlating events requires a common identifier for the event source.

trans-unit.source: For example, a user ID, session ID, or other piece of data that is a) unique and b) included in all data sent to Storm.
trans-unit.target: For example, a user ID, session ID, or other piece of data that is a) unique and b) included in all data sent to Storm.

trans-unit.source: This example uses a GUID value to represent a session ID.
trans-unit.target: This example uses a GUID value to represent a session ID.

trans-unit.source: This example consists of two HDInsight clusters:
trans-unit.target: This example consists of two HDInsight clusters:

trans-unit.source: HBase: persistent data store for historical data
trans-unit.target: HBase: persistent data store for historical data

trans-unit.source: Storm: used to ingest incoming data
trans-unit.target: Storm: used to ingest incoming data

trans-unit.source: The data is randomly generated by the Storm topology, and consists of the following items:
trans-unit.target: The data is randomly generated by the Storm topology, and consists of the following items:

trans-unit.source: Session ID: a GUID that uniquely identifies each session
trans-unit.target: Session ID: a GUID that uniquely identifies each session

trans-unit.source: Event: a START or END event.
trans-unit.target: Event: a START or END event.

trans-unit.source: For this example, START always occurs before END
trans-unit.target: For this example, START always occurs before END

trans-unit.source: Time: the time of the event.
trans-unit.target: Time: the time of the event.

trans-unit.source: This data is processed and stored in HBase.
trans-unit.target: This data is processed and stored in HBase.

trans-unit.source: Storm topology
trans-unit.target: Storm topology

trans-unit.source: When a session starts, a START event is received by the topology and logged to HBase.
trans-unit.target: When a session starts, a START event is received by the topology and logged to HBase.

trans-unit.source: When an END event is received, the topology retrieves the START event and calculates the time between the two events.
trans-unit.target: When an END event is received, the topology retrieves the START event and calculates the time between the two events.

trans-unit.source: This Duration value is then stored in HBase along with the END event information.
trans-unit.target: This Duration value is then stored in HBase along with the END event information.

trans-unit.source: While this topology demonstrates the basic pattern, a production solution would need to take design for the following scenarios:
trans-unit.target: While this topology demonstrates the basic pattern, a production solution would need to take design for the following scenarios:

trans-unit.source: - Events arriving out of order
trans-unit.target: - Events arriving out of order

trans-unit.source: - Duplicate events
trans-unit.target: - Duplicate events

trans-unit.source: - Dropped events
trans-unit.target: - Dropped events

trans-unit.source: The sample topology is composed of the following components:
trans-unit.target: The sample topology is composed of the following components:

trans-unit.source: Session.cs: simulates a user session by creating a random session ID, start time, and how long the session will last
trans-unit.target: Session.cs: simulates a user session by creating a random session ID, start time, and how long the session will last

trans-unit.source: Spout.cs: creates 100 sessions, emits a START event, waits the random timeout for each session and then emits an END event.
trans-unit.target: Spout.cs: creates 100 sessions, emits a START event, waits the random timeout for each session and then emits an END event.

trans-unit.source: Then recycles ended sessions to generate new ones.
trans-unit.target: Then recycles ended sessions to generate new ones.

trans-unit.source: HBaseLookupBolt.cs: uses the session ID to look up session information from HBase.
trans-unit.target: HBaseLookupBolt.cs: uses the session ID to look up session information from HBase.

trans-unit.source: When an END event is processed, it finds the corresponding START event and calculates the duration of the session.
trans-unit.target: When an END event is processed, it finds the corresponding START event and calculates the duration of the session.

trans-unit.source: HBaseBolt.cs: Stores information into HBase.
trans-unit.target: HBaseBolt.cs: Stores information into HBase.

trans-unit.source: TypeHelper.cs: Helps with type conversion when reading from/writing to HBase.
trans-unit.target: TypeHelper.cs: Helps with type conversion when reading from/writing to HBase.

trans-unit.source: HBase schema
trans-unit.target: HBase schema

trans-unit.source: In HBase, the data is stored in a table with the following schema/settings:
trans-unit.target: In HBase, the data is stored in a table with the following schema/settings:

trans-unit.source: Row key: the session ID is used as the key for rows in this table
trans-unit.target: Row key: the session ID is used as the key for rows in this table

trans-unit.source: Column family: the family name is 'cf'.
trans-unit.target: Column family: the family name is 'cf'.

trans-unit.source: Columns stored in this family are:
trans-unit.target: Columns stored in this family are:

trans-unit.source: event: START or END
trans-unit.target: event: START or END

trans-unit.source: time: the time in milliseconds that the event occured
trans-unit.target: time: the time in milliseconds that the event occured

trans-unit.source: duration: the length between START and END event
trans-unit.target: duration: the length between START and END event

trans-unit.source: VERSIONS: the 'cf' family is set to retain 5 versions of each row
trans-unit.target: VERSIONS: the 'cf' family is set to retain 5 versions of each row

trans-unit.source: Versions are a log of previous values stored for a specific row key.
trans-unit.target: Versions are a log of previous values stored for a specific row key.

trans-unit.source: By default, HBase only returns the value for the most recent version of a row.
trans-unit.target: By default, HBase only returns the value for the most recent version of a row.

trans-unit.source: In this case, the same row is used for all events (START, END.)
trans-unit.target: In this case, the same row is used for all events (START, END.)

trans-unit.source: each version of a row is identified by the timestamp value.
trans-unit.target: each version of a row is identified by the timestamp value.

trans-unit.source: This provides a historical view of events logged for a specific ID.
trans-unit.target: This provides a historical view of events logged for a specific ID.

trans-unit.source: Download the project
trans-unit.target: Download the project

trans-unit.source: The sample project can be downloaded from <link><linkText>hdinsight-storm-eventcorrelation</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: The sample project can be downloaded from <link><linkText>hdinsight-storm-eventcorrelation</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: This download contains the following C# projects:
trans-unit.target: This download contains the following C# projects:

trans-unit.source: CorrelationTopology: C# Storm topology that randomly emits start and end events for user sessions.
trans-unit.target: CorrelationTopology: C# Storm topology that randomly emits start and end events for user sessions.

trans-unit.source: Each session lasts between 1 and 5 minutes.
trans-unit.target: Each session lasts between 1 and 5 minutes.

trans-unit.source: SessionInfo: C# console application that creates the HBase table, and provides example queries to return information about stored session data.
trans-unit.target: SessionInfo: C# console application that creates the HBase table, and provides example queries to return information about stored session data.

trans-unit.source: Create the table
trans-unit.target: Create the table

trans-unit.source: Open the SessionInfo project in Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: Open the SessionInfo project in Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, right-click the SessionInfo project and select Properties.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, right-click the SessionInfo project and select Properties.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Screenshot of menu with properties selected</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Screenshot of menu with properties selected</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Select Settings, then set the following values:
trans-unit.target: Select Settings, then set the following values:

trans-unit.source: HBaseClusterURL: the URL to your HBase cluster.
trans-unit.target: HBaseClusterURL: the URL to your HBase cluster.

trans-unit.source: For example, https://myhbasecluster.azurehdinsight.net
trans-unit.target: For example, https://myhbasecluster.azurehdinsight.net

trans-unit.source: HBaseClusterUserName: the admin/HTTP user account for your cluster
trans-unit.target: HBaseClusterUserName: the admin/HTTP user account for your cluster

trans-unit.source: HBaseClusterPassword: the password for the admin/HTTP user account
trans-unit.target: HBaseClusterPassword: the password for the admin/HTTP user account

trans-unit.source: HBaseTableName: the name of the table to use with this example
trans-unit.target: HBaseTableName: the name of the table to use with this example

trans-unit.source: HBaseTableColumnFamily: The column family name
trans-unit.target: HBaseTableColumnFamily: The column family name

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Image of settings dialog</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Image of settings dialog</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Run the solution.
trans-unit.target: Run the solution.

trans-unit.source: When prompted, select the 'c' key to create the table on your HBase cluster.
trans-unit.target: When prompted, select the 'c' key to create the table on your HBase cluster.

trans-unit.source: Build and deploy the Storm topology
trans-unit.target: Build and deploy the Storm topology

trans-unit.source: Open the CorrelationTopology solution in Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: Open the CorrelationTopology solution in Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, right click the CorrelationTopology project and select properties.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, right click the CorrelationTopology project and select properties.

trans-unit.source: In the properties window, select Settings and provide the following information.
trans-unit.target: In the properties window, select Settings and provide the following information.

trans-unit.source: The first 5 should be the same values used by the SessionInfo project:
trans-unit.target: The first 5 should be the same values used by the SessionInfo project:

trans-unit.source: HBaseClusterURL: the URL to your HBase cluster.
trans-unit.target: HBaseClusterURL: the URL to your HBase cluster.

trans-unit.source: For example, https://myhbasecluster.azurehdinsight.net
trans-unit.target: For example, https://myhbasecluster.azurehdinsight.net

trans-unit.source: HBaseClusterUserName: the admin/HTTP user account for your cluster
trans-unit.target: HBaseClusterUserName: the admin/HTTP user account for your cluster

trans-unit.source: HBaseClusterPassword: the password for the admin/HTTP user account
trans-unit.target: HBaseClusterPassword: the password for the admin/HTTP user account

trans-unit.source: HBaseTableName: the name of the table to use with this example.
trans-unit.target: HBaseTableName: the name of the table to use with this example.

trans-unit.source: This should contain the same table name as that used in the SessionInfo project
trans-unit.target: This should contain the same table name as that used in the SessionInfo project

trans-unit.source: HBaseTableColumnFamily: The column family name.
trans-unit.target: HBaseTableColumnFamily: The column family name.

trans-unit.source: This should contain the same column family name as that used in the SessionInfo project
trans-unit.target: This should contain the same column family name as that used in the SessionInfo project

trans-unit.source: Do not change the HBaseTableColumnNames, as the defaults are the names used by SessionInfo to retrieve data.
trans-unit.target: Do not change the HBaseTableColumnNames, as the defaults are the names used by SessionInfo to retrieve data.

trans-unit.source: Save the properties, then build the project.
trans-unit.target: Save the properties, then build the project.

trans-unit.source: In Solution Explorer, right click the project and select Submit to Storm on HDInsight.
trans-unit.target: In Solution Explorer, right click the project and select Submit to Storm on HDInsight.

trans-unit.source: If prompted, enter the credentials for your Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: If prompted, enter the credentials for your Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Image of the submit to storm menu item</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Image of the submit to storm menu item</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the Submit Topology dialog, select the Storm cluster that will run this topology.
trans-unit.target: In the Submit Topology dialog, select the Storm cluster that will run this topology.

trans-unit.source: The first time you submit a topology, it may take a few seconds to retrieve the name of your HDInsight clusters.
trans-unit.target: The first time you submit a topology, it may take a few seconds to retrieve the name of your HDInsight clusters.

trans-unit.source: Once the topology has been uploaded and submitted to the cluster, the Storm Topology View will open and display the running topology.
trans-unit.target: Once the topology has been uploaded and submitted to the cluster, the Storm Topology View will open and display the running topology.

trans-unit.source: Select the CorrelationTopology and use the refresh button at the top right of the page to refresh the topology information.
trans-unit.target: Select the CorrelationTopology and use the refresh button at the top right of the page to refresh the topology information.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Image of the topology view</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Image of the topology view</linkText>

trans-unit.source: When the topology begins generating data, the value in the Emitted column will increment.
trans-unit.target: When the topology begins generating data, the value in the Emitted column will increment.

trans-unit.source: If the Storm Topology View does not open automatically, use the following steps to open it:
trans-unit.target: If the Storm Topology View does not open automatically, use the following steps to open it:

trans-unit.source: 1. In Solution Explorer, expand Azure, and then expand HDInsight.
trans-unit.target: 1. In Solution Explorer, expand Azure, and then expand HDInsight.

trans-unit.source: 2. Right click the Storm cluster that the topology is running on, and then select View Storm Topologies
trans-unit.target: 2. Right click the Storm cluster that the topology is running on, and then select View Storm Topologies

trans-unit.source: Query the data
trans-unit.target: Query the data

trans-unit.source: Once data has been emitted, use the following steps to query the data.
trans-unit.target: Once data has been emitted, use the following steps to query the data.

trans-unit.source: Return to the SessionInfo project.
trans-unit.target: Return to the SessionInfo project.

trans-unit.source: If not running, start a new instance of it.
trans-unit.target: If not running, start a new instance of it.

trans-unit.source: When prompted, select s to search for START event.
trans-unit.target: When prompted, select s to search for START event.

trans-unit.source: You will be prompted to enter a start and end time to define a time range - only events between these two times will be returned.
trans-unit.target: You will be prompted to enter a start and end time to define a time range - only events between these two times will be returned.

trans-unit.source: Use the following format when entering the start and end times: HH:MM and 'am' or 'pm'.
trans-unit.target: Use the following format when entering the start and end times: HH:MM and 'am' or 'pm'.

trans-unit.source: For example, 11:20pm.
trans-unit.target: For example, 11:20pm.

trans-unit.source: Since the topology has just started, use a start time from before it was deployed, and an end time of now.
trans-unit.target: Since the topology has just started, use a start time from before it was deployed, and an end time of now.

trans-unit.source: This should capture most of the START events that were generated when it started.
trans-unit.target: This should capture most of the START events that were generated when it started.

trans-unit.source: When the query runs, you should see a list of entries similar to the following:
trans-unit.target: When the query runs, you should see a list of entries similar to the following:

trans-unit.source: Searching for END events works the same as START events.
trans-unit.target: Searching for END events works the same as START events.

trans-unit.source: However, END events are generated randomly between 1 and 5 minutes after the START event.
trans-unit.target: However, END events are generated randomly between 1 and 5 minutes after the START event.

trans-unit.source: So you may have to try a few time ranges in order to find the END events.
trans-unit.target: So you may have to try a few time ranges in order to find the END events.

trans-unit.source: END events will also contain the duration of the session - the difference between the START event time and END event time.
trans-unit.target: END events will also contain the duration of the session - the difference between the START event time and END event time.

trans-unit.source: Here is an example of data for END events:
trans-unit.target: Here is an example of data for END events:

trans-unit.source: While the time values you enter are in local time, the time returned from the query will be UTC.
trans-unit.target: While the time values you enter are in local time, the time returned from the query will be UTC.

trans-unit.source: Stop the topology
trans-unit.target: Stop the topology

trans-unit.source: When you are ready to stop the topology, return to the CorrelationTopology project in Visual Studio.
trans-unit.target: When you are ready to stop the topology, return to the CorrelationTopology project in Visual Studio.

trans-unit.source: In the Storm Topology View, select the topology and then use the Kill button at the top of the topology view.
trans-unit.target: In the Storm Topology View, select the topology and then use the Kill button at the top of the topology view.

trans-unit.source: Next steps
trans-unit.target: Next steps

trans-unit.source: For more Storm examples, see <link><linkText>Example topologies for Storm on HDInsight</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more Storm examples, see <link><linkText>Example topologies for Storm on HDInsight</linkText><title></title></link>.
